node.title: Attack Left Flight Attendant With Concussion and Facial Injury, Authorities Say
node.alt: Flight 976, from Kennedy Airport in New York to Santa Ana, Calif., was diverted to Denver International Airport, where a passenger was taken into custody and a flight attendant was taken to a hospital.
node.description: The chief executive of American Airlines called the violent encounter on a California-bound flight from New York last week “one of the worst displays of unruly behavior we’ve ever witnessed.”
node.content: ["An American Airlines flight attendant who was struck on her nose by a passenger last week sustained a concussion and had to be taken by stretcher from the plane after it was diverted to Denver, where the passenger was arrested, according to a criminal complaint filed with the U.S. attorney\u2019s office for Colorado.", "The passenger, Brian Hsu, 20, of Irvine, Calif., was charged with assault and interference with a flight crew, according to the criminal complaint.", "The flight attendant was taken to a hospital after the flight, American Airlines Flight 976 from New York City to Santa Ana, Calif., was diverted to Denver International Airport on Wednesday.", "Doctors found that the flight attendant had a concussion, according to the filing from an F.B.I. agent who investigated the case. She underwent a CT scan, but doctors were \u201cunable to determine if her nose was fractured because of the swelling,\u201d the filing said.", "According to statements that passengers who witnessed the episode made to the F.B.I. agent, the flight attendant asked Mr. Hsu to stay away from the bathroom, and Mr. Hsu \u201cpunched her in the face with sufficient force to cause her to hit the lavatory door.\u201d Another witness described the passenger \u201cstriking her with his fist in a way that appeared practiced or trained.\u201d", "After the flight attendant was struck, another flight attendant repeatedly asked Mr. Hsu to sit in his seat, according to the filing. Mr. Hsu did not initially comply but finally sat down, and then, one witness told the authorities, Mr. Hsu was restrained with tape and later \u201cplastic bonds.\u201d", "Mr. Hsu told the authorities a different account. He said that he was returning to California from New York after having brain surgery in Rhode Island to \u201creconstruct portions of his skull\u201d after he was assaulted in New York City in fall 2020 and sustained a skull injury, according to the filing.", "Mr. Hsu said he got up from his seat on the plane to use the restroom and stretch. While he was stretching, Mr. Hsu said, he accidentally bumped the flight attendant, and she began swinging at him with her hands, the filing said. Mr. Hsu said that he \u201cbacked up towards his seat and raised his hands defensively\u201d and that she \u201chit her nose against the palm of his right hand.\u201d", "Mr. Hsu told the authorities that he sometimes experiences a \u201cmental \u2018fog\u2019\u201d and that \u201che became scared because an impact to his head in its current state could cause him severe injury or death,\u201d according to the complaint.", "The flight attendant told the authorities that she had told Mr. Hsu he could not use the bathroom because the pilot had turned on the plane\u2019s \u201cfasten seatbelt\u201d signs, and that he needed to return to his seat, according to the filing.", "Mr. Hsu then \u201ccharged at her, flailing his arms,\u201d the complaint said.", "A federal public defender assigned to represent Mr. Hsu did not immediately respond to requests for comment on Monday night.", "In a video message posted on Instagram, Doug Parker, the chief executive of American Airlines, called the encounter \u201cone of the worst displays of unruly behavior we\u2019ve ever witnessed.\u201d", "Mr. Hsu will never be allowed to fly again with American Airlines, Mr. Parker said in the video message, adding that such altercations are \u201chappening far too often.\u201d", "\u201cThis type of behavior has to stop,\u201d he said.", "The episode is one of thousands that have occurred this year, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. Through Oct. 26, the F.A.A. had recorded more than 4,900 reports of unruly passengers this year, in addition to more than 3,500 face mask-related incident reports.", "In a statement on Oct. 28, the Association of Professional Flight Attendants said that barring the passenger from future American Airlines flights \u201cdoes not address the root problem,\u201d and called for the F.A.A. and the Department of Transportation to implement a \u201cno-fly\u201d list to include all airlines.", "\u201cWe need to keep pushing,\u201d the association said. \u201cWe need more police in airports, increased fines for egregious behavior, and stronger, enforceable criminal penalties.\u201d", "In a statement in September, Steve Dickson, the F.A.A. administrator, said the number of incidents had dropped after the agency instituted a \u201czero-tolerance\u201d policy toward unruly passengers; the policy opts for directly issuing fines instead of warning letters.", "\u201cOur work is having an impact and the trend is moving in the right direction,\u201d Mr. Dickson said. \u201cBut we need the progress to continue. This remains a serious safety threat, and one incident is one too many.\u201d"]
